events.title: Trump's World's Fair Casino opens in Atlantic City
events.description: Trump officially opens the Trump World's Fair casino in Atlantic City after spending $48 million renovating the old Trump Regency/Atlantis hotel. The casino addition featured 500 hotel rooms and expanded Trump's Atlantic City holdings.

moneyFlow.description: Trump, through Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts, invested $48 million to renovate the old Trump Regency/Atlantis hotel into the Trump World's Fair casino in Atlantic City. This substantial investment expanded Trump's footprint in the Atlantic City gaming market, adding 500 hotel rooms to his portfolio during a period of financial recovery following his early 1990s difficulties.

events.title: Trump Casino riverboat opens in Gary, Indiana
events.description: Trump expands his casino operations beyond Atlantic City with the opening of the Trump Casino riverboat in Gary, Indiana. This came after securing a casino license in 1994 and represents Trump's entry into the Chicagoland gaming market.

moneyFlow.description: The Trump Casino riverboat in Gary, Indiana represented a $153 million investment by Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts, in partnership with local businessman Don Barden. This major expansion beyond Atlantic City into the Chicagoland gaming market followed Trump's successful securing of an Indiana casino license in 1994, and was part of Trump's broader strategy to diversify his gaming operations geographically.

sources.description: 1993: Trump gambles on Gary with riverboat casino proposal

events.title: Trump acquires Miss Universe Organization
events.description: Trump purchases the Miss Universe Organization from ITT Corp, gaining ownership of Miss Universe, Miss USA, and Miss Teen USA pageants. The deal included a broadcast partnership with CBS, marking Trump's expansion into media and entertainment beyond real estate.

moneyFlow.description: Trump purchased the Miss Universe Organization from ITT Corp for approximately $10 million, acquiring the Miss Universe, Miss USA, and Miss Teen USA pageants. This acquisition represented Trump's strategic expansion into media and entertainment beyond his core real estate business, providing brand extension opportunities and media visibility. The Panama Papers note that the Miss Universe Organization later held pageants in offshore jurisdictions such as Cyprus, often involving offshore-fueled funding arrangements.

events.title: Pritzker family buys out Trump's stake in Grand Hyatt New York
events.description: The Pritzker family purchases Trump's 50% ownership stake in the Grand Hyatt New York hotel, ending a partnership that began in the late 1970s with the renovation of the former Commodore Hotel. This represented Trump's exit from one of his earliest major Manhattan property developments.

moneyFlow.description: The Pritzker family purchased Trump's 50% stake in the Grand Hyatt New York hotel for $140 million. This transaction ended a partnership that began in the late 1970s with the renovation of the former Commodore Hotel, providing Trump with significant liquidity as he continued to rebuild his finances following the difficulties of the early 1990s. The Pritzkers are known from the Panama/Paradise Papers to utilize offshore entities for their business operations.

events.title: Trump separates from Marla Maples
events.description: Trump and his second wife Marla Maples separate after nearly four years of marriage. The separation would lead to a divorce in 1997, with Maples reportedly receiving approximately $2 million according to their prenuptial agreement.

moneyFlow.description: Trump's separation from Marla Maples in December 1996 led to their divorce in 1997, with Maples reportedly receiving a settlement of approximately $2 million according to their prenuptial agreement. This personal financial outflow was relatively modest compared to Trump's business transactions during this period.

entity-001.name: Donald J. Trump
entity-001.description: Real estate developer, businessman, and casino operator. In 1996, expanded his brand beyond real estate into media with the Miss Universe acquisition, while also growing his casino portfolio with new properties in Atlantic City and Gary, Indiana.

entity-050.name: Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts, Inc.
entity-050.description: Trump's publicly traded casino company that operated his gaming properties. In 1996, the company expanded with the opening of Trump's World's Fair Casino in Atlantic City and the Trump Casino riverboat in Gary, Indiana.

entity-051.name: Miss Universe Organization
entity-051.description: Beauty pageant organization purchased by Donald Trump in 1996 from ITT Corp. The company owned and operated the Miss Universe, Miss USA, and Miss Teen USA beauty pageants. The Panama Papers researchers noted that the organization later held events in offshore jurisdictions including Cyprus, often involving permissive tax arrangements with host countries.
entity-051.notes: While not directly implicated in the Panama Papers, the organization's later operations in offshore jurisdictions were noted by ICIJ researchers as part of the pattern of Trump businesses operating in tax-advantaged locations.

entity-052.name: Pritzker family
entity-052.description: Wealthy American family who owned the Hyatt hotel chain and various other business interests. In 1996, they bought out Trump's 50% stake in the Grand Hyatt New York, ending a partnership that began in the late 1970s. The Panama Papers revealed the Pritzkers' extensive use of offshore structures, with Thomas Jay Pritzker appearing as a shareholder in multiple Bermuda companies.
entity-052.notes: The Paradise Papers identified multiple offshore entities connected to the Pritzker family, including Western International Financial Group Ltd., THL Ltd., and The Jay Pritzker Fund Inc. in the Bahamas.

entity-053.name: Marla Maples
entity-053.description: American actress and television personality who was Donald Trump's second wife from 1993 to 1999. They separated in 1996 after nearly four years of marriage.

relationships.description: Trump, through his publicly traded Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts, opened the Trump World's Fair casino in Atlantic City, expanding his gaming footprint.
Trump, through his company Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts, expanded his casino operations beyond Atlantic City by opening the Trump Casino riverboat in Gary, Indiana.
Trump acquired the Miss Universe Organization in 1996, expanding his brand beyond real estate into media and entertainment.
Trump sold his 50% stake in the Grand Hyatt New York to the Pritzker family, ending a partnership that began in the late 1970s.
Trump and Marla Maples separated in December 1996 after nearly four years of marriage. They would divorce in 1997.

transactions.description: Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts spent $48 million renovating and opening Trump's World's Fair Casino in Atlantic City.
Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts developed and opened the Trump Casino riverboat in Gary, Indiana, in partnership with local businessman Don Barden, expanding beyond Atlantic City.
transactions.notes: The Trump Casino in Gary reportedly cost approximately $153 million to build and launch, representing Trump's expansion into the Midwest gaming market.

transactions.description: The Pritzker family purchased Trump's 50% stake in the Grand Hyatt New York hotel for approximately $140 million.
Trump purchased the Miss Universe Organization from ITT Corp for approximately $10 million, acquiring the Miss Universe, Miss USA, and Miss Teen USA pageants.
transactions.notes: This acquisition represented Trump's strategic expansion into media and entertainment beyond his core real estate business.

transactions.description: Trump's separation from Marla Maples in December 1996 led to a settlement of approximately $2 million according to their prenuptial agreement when they divorced in 1997.
